Text: The Mighty One, God the LORD, speaks and summons the earth from the rising of the sun to the place where it sets.
Context: The psalm begins by establishing the sovereign authority of God, who addresses the entire earth.

Text: From Zion, perfect in beauty, God shines forth.
Context: God’s radiance and perfection are associated with Zion, a metaphoric representation of His presence and the ideal of beauty.

Text: Our God approaches and will not be silent; devouring fire precedes Him, and a tempest rages around Him.
Context: The imagery evokes the majesty and power of God‘s presence, suggesting He is a force that commands attention and respect.

Text: He summons the heavens above, and the earth, that He may judge His people:
Context: This introduces the theme of divine judgement, with God as the judge of all.

Text: ”Gather to Me My faithful ones, who made a covenant with Me by sacrifice.“
Context: The call is for the faithful, highlighting the covenant relationship between God and His people involving sacrifice.

Text: The heavens proclaim His righteousness, for God Himself is Judge. Selah
Context: The reliability and righteousness of God’s judgement are affirmed by the heavens themselves, a poetic expression of divine witness.

Text: ”Hear, O My people, and I will speak, O Israel, and I will testify against you: I am God, your God.
Context: The prelude to God‘s charge against His people, emphasizing His authority and their relationship.

Text: “I do not rebuke you for your sacrifices or for your burnt offerings, which are continually before Me.”
Context: God acknowledges the people’s religious practices, signifying His recognition of their sacrifices.

Text: “I have no need of a bull from your barn, nor of goats from your pens,”
Context: God asserts His self-sufficiency, indicating that He is not dependent on the people‘s offerings for sustenance.

Text: “for every animal of the forest is Mine, and the cattle on a thousand hills.”
Context: God speaks of His ownership of all creation, which negates any notion that He could be in need of anything from humans.

Text: “I know every bird in the mountains, and the creatures of the field are Mine.”
Context: A further assertion of God’s comprehensive sovereignty over creation.

Text: “If I were hungry, I would not tell you, for the world is Mine, and all that is in it.”
Context: God emphasizes His independence and the irrelevance of human offerings in fulfilling His needs.

Text: “Do I eat the flesh of bulls, or drink the blood of goats?”
Context: A rhetorical question highlighting the absurdity of thinking that God would require food like a human.

Text: “Offer to God a sacrifice of thanksgiving, and fulfill your vows to the Most High.”
Context: The focus shifts to the kind of sacrifices God truly desires—those of thanksgiving and faithfulness.

Text: “Call upon Me in the day of trouble; I will deliver you, and you will honor Me.”
Context: God promises support in times of trouble in exchange for honor; implies a reciprocal relationship.

Text: “But to the wicked, God says: ‘What right have you to recite My statutes or take My covenant on your lips?’”
Context: God challenges the wicked, questioning their hypocrisy in invoking His laws and covenant.

Text: “You hate My instruction and cast My words behind you.”
Context: Accusation against the wicked for their disregard for divine instruction.

Text: “When you see a thief, you join him; you throw in your lot with adulterers.”
Context: The wicked are indicted for their complicity in and approval of immoral acts.

Text: “You use your mouth for evil and harness your tongue to deceit.”
Context: An expression of God‘s disapproval of wicked speech and deceit.

Text: “You sit and testify against your brother; you slander your own mother’s son.”
Context: The wicked are accused of undermining family through slander, a social and moral transgression.

Text: “These things you have done, and I kept silent; you thought I was just like you. But now I rebuke you and lay the charge before you.”
Context: God warns the wicked that His previous silence should not have been misinterpreted as approval or complacency.

Text: “Consider this, you who forget God, lest I tear you apart, and there be none to rescue.”
Context: A stern warning to those who neglect their relationship with God, suggesting dire consequences.

Text: “He who sacrifices a thank offering honors Me, and to him who orders his conduct aright I will show the salvation of God.”
Context: An affirmation of those who honor God through thanksgiving and righteous living, with a promise of salvation.
